title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part B(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one benefit of using synthetic fertilizers in the garden, such as any of the following:

· The nutrients in synthetic fertilizers are readily available and can be taken up by the plant in a short period of time (days, not weeks).

· Synthetic fertilizers are formulated to have a certain ratio of nutrients, so only the limited nutrient(s) can be added to the soil.

· Synthetic fertilizers are inexpensive and easily available.

· Synthetic fertilizers are inexpensive and easily available.

title: Part B(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe correct evidence to justify the claim that composting is a more sustainable agricultural practice, such as any of the following:

· Production of synthetic fertilizer production requires the burning of fossil fuels and composting does not.

· Compost maintains soil porosity, which limits runoff and synthetic fertilizers do not.

· Compost reduces the amount of waste generated by using food scraps, paper, and yard wastes to create the organic fertilizer.

· Composting reduces the amount of atmospheric methane since there is less food waste decomposing in landfills.

· Compost can be produced on site and does not require transportation (less CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGdbGaae4ta8aadaWgaaWcbaWdbiaaikdaa8aabeaaaaa@38C4@ , less fossil fuel combustion).

The response describes correct evidence to justify the claim that composting is a more sustainable agricultural practice, such as one of the following:

· Production of synthetic fertilizer production requires the burning of fossil fuels and composting does not.

· Compost maintains soil porosity, which limits runoff and synthetic fertilizers do not.

· Compost reduces the amount of waste generated by using food scraps, paper, and yard wastes to create the organic fertilizer.

· Composting reduces the amount of atmospheric methane since there is less food waste decomposing in landfills.

· Compost can be produced on site and does not require transportation (less CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGdbGaae4ta8aadaWgaaWcbaWdbiaaikdaa8aabeaaaaa@38C4@ , less fossil fuel combustion).
